title: Ben Selvin & His Orchestra - Dardanella (1919-31) ASV
description:
BEN SELVIN & HIS ORCHESTRA - DARDANELLA

*****************************************************************

Benjamin B. ("Ben") Selvin (March 5, 1898 Ã¢â‚¬â€œ July 15, 1980), son of Russian-immigrant Jewish parents, was a musician, bandleader, record producer and innovator in recorded music. He was known as The Dean of Recorded Music.

Selvin started his professional life at age 15 as a fiddle player in New York City night clubs (passing as older).

Six years later, as leader of his own dance band, the "Novelty Orchestra," Selvin released the biggest-selling popular song in the first quarter-century of recorded music, "Dardanella".

According to The Guinness Book of World Records, Selvin recorded more musical sides (on 78-rpm discs) than any other person. One reason for this prolific output is that he recorded for dozens of different labels during this high-growth time in the industry, using a different name (or slightly different name) for each label. Selvin's output has been estimated at 13,000 to 20,000 song titles (the liner notes say "9,000-odd titles").

*****************************************************************

BEN SELVIN & HIS ORCHESTRA - DARDANELLA

01. Dardanella
02. I'm Forever Blowing Bubbles
03. Manhattan
04. Sentimental Me
05. I Can't Give You Anything But Love (Vaughn DeLeath - vocal)
06. You're The Cream In My Coffee (Jack Parker - vocal)
07. The Broadway Melody (Jack Parker - vocal)
08. Am I Blue (Smith Ballew - vocal)
09. Thank You Father (Jack Teagarden - vocal)
10. Happy Days Are Here Again (The Rollickers - vocal)
11. The Free And Easy (Smith Ballew - vocal)
12. Dancing With Tears In My Eyes (Ruth Etting - vocal)
13. My Man From Caroline (Eva Taylor - vocal)
14. I Got Rhythm (Ethel Waters - vocal)
15. Three Little Words (Ethel Waters - vocal)
16. Cheerful Little Earful (Helen Rowland - vocal)
17. You Said It (Helen Rowland and Paul Smith - vocal)
18. Last Dollar (Dick Robertson - vocal)
19. I Found  A Million-Dollar Baby
20. Dancing In The Dark (Dick Robertson - vocal)
21. When The Moon Comes Over The Mountain (Kate Smith - vocal)
22. Little Mary Brown (The Wallace Trio - vocals)
23. Between The Devil And The Deep Blue Sea (Dick Robertson - vocal)
24. You're My Everything (Helen Rowland - vocal)

2000 ASV "Living Era"

*****************************************************************

I am not going to type out the session info for this compilation. MORE INFO ON SCANS

It includes Jimmy Dorsey, Tommy Dorsey, Joe Venuti, Manny Klein, Eddie Lang, Benny Goodman, Dick McDonaugh, Ethel Waters, Jack Teagarden, Smith Ballew, and many others.

The first two tracks were recorded in 1919. The remaining tracks were recorded between 1925 and 1931.

*****************************************************************
